content:
EDIT:

* Added constraints for [[N]]

* Added [[A]] && [[B]] as variables

Why is the Large Validator > Large Testcase, CG says to put larger numbers in tests and smaller in validators. In this clash everyone got 75% as validator was too big. So i changed the final validator

This one is really not solvable in reverse mode. 
The examples suggest that one just have to decompose N into two factors with one less than the other if possible. 

here is a code in ocaml which pass ALL the tests but not ALL validators. 

Ocaml: 
(* Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse *)
(* the standard input according to the problem statement. *)

let n = int_of_string (input_line stdin) in
let rec f k n = 
    if k<=n
    then
    if n mod k = 0 
    then k::f k (n/k) 
    else f (k+1) n
    else []
in 
let l = f 2 n in
let rec f l = 
    match l with 
        | [a] -> 1,a
        | [a;b] -> min a b,max a b
        | a::b::l -> f ((a*b)::l)
        | [] -> assert false
in 
let a,b = f l in 
Format.printf "%d*%d" a b

Another one in ruby with the same problem (not my code):
require 'prime'
n = gets.to_i
a = Prime.prime_division(n)[-1][0]
puts [a, n/a].sort*?*


I thus remove reverse mode for now.

Should I make it reverse too?
Or will it be too hard?
I didn't notice, thanks a lot!
I've updated Output section. "A â‰¤ B" shouldn't be in Constraints section. It's part of the output requirement.
